headline.main: One Hotel's Fight to the Finish; At the Marriott, a Portal to Safety as the Towers Fell

byline.original: By JIM DWYER and FORD FESSENDEN

docs.abstract: Article recalls dramas inside Marriott Hotel at 3 World Trade Center a year ago, as south tower collapsed around hotel; in its final 102 minutes, Marriott Hotel served as mouth of tunnel, a runway in and out of burning towers for perhaps a thousand people or more; about 50 people died in World Trade Center complex's hotel, at least 41 of them firefighters; photo; drawings (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: It was only a hotel, a 22-story dwarf tucked under colossal buildings, but in its final 102 minutes, the Marriott Hotel at 3 World Trade Center served as the mouth of a tunnel, a runway in and out of the burning towers for perhaps a thousand people or more. On this middle ground, a ferocious struggle to live was waged, starting from 9:59, when the south tower collapsed and cleaved the hotel from top to bottom.

headline.kicker: HOTEL CHECK-IN: T-1 LINES AND BATH BALMS
headline.main: Miami: A new Marriott sheds its traditional image in South Beach

docs.abstract: Article on five hotels that offer latest in high-tech connections, and high style comfort; Ann Crittenden reviews new Marriott at South Beach in Miami; photos (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: My overnight stay at the new Marriott at South Beach in Miami began on a warm note. As my taxi pulled up at the entrance, two young men in crisp white shirts and blue shorts bounded forward to open the door, welcomed me effusively and escorted my luggage up the stairs. Glancing at the orange, gold and cream confection with a little Art Deco turret on top, I wasn't sure I was in the right place. ''Is this the new Marriott?'' I asked tentatively. ''It sure is,'' said the one with the spiky, moussed hair, grinning.

docs.abstract: E M Statler buys Iroquois Hotel in Buffalo
docs.lead_paragraph: BUFFALO, N.Y., May 30.--Sale of the Hotel Iroquois, the oldest of the large hotels in Buffalo, to E.M. Statler was announced tonight, Mr. Statler said that he would continue operation of the hotel for the present.
